The lower house of Congress unanimously passed Mexico's first freedom of information bill Wednesday.

The lower house of Congress unanimously passed Mexico's first freedom of information bill today. The Senate is expected to approve the measure, which would compel the government to release most public records.

Under the law, the federal government, the legislature, the courts and the national bank would have to publish basic information on decisions and operations. Officials who refuse to disclose information or destroy documents could be prosecuted.

In Mexico, basic information on the government and federal records of land deals and loans have been treated with secrecy, and past presidents have purged the national archives of records that might tend to incriminate them.
